fields.Chapter Title: "Anna Stanislawska's Orphan Girl of 1685: Autobiography of a Coerced Marriage"
fields.Book Title: Women on the Edge in Early Modern Europe.  (Collection of Essays edited by Aidan Norrie and Lisa Hopkins)
fields.Description/Abstract:
Anna Stanisławska wrote an autobiography describing forced marriage to a mentally ill man who terrorized her, but she managed escape.  The case was so extraordinary that Jan Andzrej Morsztyn wrote, “A Maid, for she knows no husband, and yet a wife,/For he lives, he to whom she was married.”
Stanisławska might have accepted her fate, but instead she used the system of law, patronage, and family connections to escape.  She describes the strategies to extricate herself, and concludes with the most damning pieces of evidence against the transacting in women.  
She wins a divorce, though not without loss.  Her account reveals a woman of character from a distant time but whose desire for liberty and self-determination is eternal.
